related_questions.question: What was the increase in Social Security from 2021 to 2022?
related_questions.snippet: Approximately 70 million Americans will see a 5.9% increase in their Social Security benefits and Supplemental Security Income (SSI) payments in 2022. Federal benefit rates increase when the cost-of-living rises, as measured by the Department of Labor's Consumer Price Index (CPI-W).

related_questions.question: How do I get the $16728 Social Security bonus?
related_questions.title: AI Overview
list: Full Retirement Age (FRA): This is the age at which you can claim your full retirement benefit amount, as determined by the year you were born. For those born in 1960 or later, FRA is 67.
Delaying Benefits: If you delay claiming benefits past your FRA, your monthly benefit will increase by a certain percentage for each month you wait.
Maximum Benefit at 70: The maximum increase in benefits is achieved by waiting until age 70 to claim Social Security.

$16,728 is an Example: The specific amount, $16,728, is not a guaranteed bonus, but a potential increase in annual benefits if you delay claiming from age 66 to 70, assuming an average benefit amount. This can vary based on individual earnings history.
Work for at least 35 years: . Opens in new tabYour Social Security benefit is based on your highest 35 years of earnings.
Maximize your earnings: . Opens in new tabHigher earnings throughout your career will result in a higher average indexed monthly earnings (AIME), which is used to calculate your benefit.
Consider spousal benefits: . Opens in new tabIf you are married, there may be strategies to maximize benefits by coordinating your claims.

Avoid working while receiving benefits early: . Opens in new tabIf you start claiming benefits before your full retirement age and continue to work, your benefits may be temporarily reduced if your earnings exceed certain thresholds.

related_questions.question: What is the Social Security Cola for 2021 2025?
related_questions.snippet: The COLA for 2025 was 2.5%, which was the lowest annual increase since 2021, when an inflationary cycle began that peaked at a 40-year high in June 2022 before easing in the years that followed. That 2.5% increase boosted the average monthly Social Security benefit by $48, TSCL found at the time.
